Settings¶

This is a module with a base class and mostly used setting classes. In general, a setting is an object attribute but with overridden attribute access methods, it is said to be a descriptor. In the code settings behave like normal variables; default value of setting as well as permissions and units can be given in the configuration file of application. A user can have access to settings via two system commands: get and set.

Base setting classes¶

class pyfrid.core.settings.BaseSetting(value, getter=None, setter=None, units='', docs='', expected=[], limits=[None, None], fixed=False, allownone=False)[source]¶

Base class of a setting. Initialization function has the following arguments:

  • value - default value of setting, it can be also a callable object;
  • getter and setter - callable objects or functions to get and to set setting value;
  • units - simple string with units name;
  • expected - a list of expected values; these values must be of the same type as setting;
  • limits - lower and upper (or None if not defined) limits for setting value;
  • fixed - if this flag is True, this setting can not be accessed with set or get command;
  • allownone - if True None value is also allowed independently of the setting type.
configure(instance, default_value=None, permissions=None)[source]¶

This function creates a record in settings registry. This record is a dictionary with a default value of a setting, its permissions and actual value, which is None by default and will be set during setting initialization. instance - an object instance which has this setting as an attribute.

class pyfrid.core.settings.BaseListSetting(value, getter=None, setter=None, units='', docs='', expected=[], limits=[None, None], fixed=False, allownone=False, numitems=None)[source]¶

Base setting class which accepts list of values. Compared to normal setting it has numitems, which defines a maximum number of items in the list.
